results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “American cinema”.
Provides a formal and cultural analysis of a classical film sequence serving as a critical how-to guide for those new to film critique.

results.title: The Edge of Hollywood
results.creator_credit: Saskia Baron, Shana Swanson, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “American cinema”.
While many of the old rules are still in force, independent filmmakers often add their dissineting voices to the forum. This program looks at some alternative visions from new talents including Spike Lee, Joel and Ethan Coen, Jim Jarmusch and Quentin Tarantino. With limited budgets, they are challenging the stylistic status quo of the Hollywood film.

results.title: The Film school generation
results.creator_credit: Steve Jenkins, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “American cinema”.
Maverick filmmakers of the 1960’s and 1970’s including Brian DePalma, Martin Scorsese and Steven Spielberg, capitalized on new technology and borrowed from the classical Hollywood and French New Wave as they as they reinvented the American film. The financial and cultural forces that contributed to their success and commercial clout are explored.

results.title: Film in the television age
results.creator_credit: Elizabeth Foster, Alain Klarer, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “American cinema”.
Television arrived in American homes just as the Hollywood studio system was collasping. As the new medium took hold, so did a new era in motion picture entertainment. Renown directors, film scholars and actors trace the influence of each medium upon the other; from the live and fresh dramas of the Golden Age of Television and the growth of Hollywood spectacles to the modern day megalithic entertainment industry.

results.title: Film noir
results.creator_credit: Jeffrey Schon, Sasha Alpert, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “American cinema”.
These cynical and pessimistic films from the 1930’s and 1940’s touched a raw nerve in Americans. Historians link the genre’s overriding paranoia to Cold War related angst over the nuclear threat and the Hollywood blacklist. Additionally, a cinematographer demonstrates the creation of lighting which gives these films their peculiar look thus emphasising the themes of corruption and urban decay.

results.title: The Combat film
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Pitkethly, Danielle Gardner, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “American cinema”.
Beginning with World War II combat films which were produced under U.S. Federal Government directives, this program examines the role of the combat film in filling a social and political need. Critics and directors describe the evolution of these films, the rise of the Vietnam film and the influence of newsreel documentaries and television news on the genre.

results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “American cinema”.
Breezy and silly to witty and intelligent, romantic comedies have been around since the 1930’s but the surface humour barely masked issues of gender and sexuality. This program reviews screwball comedies including “It happened one night” and “His girl Friday” and analyses more recent interpretations of the genre by directors like Nora Ephron and James Brooks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Molly Ornati, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History

results.title: The Western
results.creator_credit: Lesley Karsten, Sasha Alpert, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “American cinema”.
The Western is an American myth that has been translated by other cultures and re-interpreted time and time again but never dies. With film clips and critical commentary on Westerns, from John Ford’s “Stagecoach” to the work of Arthur Penn, Sam Peckinpah and Clint Eastwood, the program traces the aesthetic evolution of the genre as well as its sociological importance.

results.title: The Star
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Pitkethly, Danielle Gardner, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “American cinema”.
Greta Garbo, Cary Grant, Dustin Hoffman - these amongst many others are names synonymous with Hollywood. Early on, Hollywood saw that recognisable talent could minimise the financial risks of film production. Critics, film scholars and studio publicists view the stars from many angles, as marketing tools, cultural icons and products of the industry. Joan Crawford is used as a case study.
